fullProgramDescription: The Department of Economics offers a major in Economics, which provides a rigorous education in economic theory, econometrics, and applied economics. Students develop a strong foundation in microeconomics, macroeconomics, and econometrics, as well as a range of elective courses in specialized areas. The program prepares students for a variety of careers in government, business, finance, and academia, as well as for graduate study in economics and related fields.
shortProgramDescription: MIT's Economics B.S. provides a rigorous education in economic theory, econometrics, and applied economics, preparing students for careers in government, business, finance, and academia, or for graduate study.
classHighlights: Core Courses: Students take a sequence of core courses in microeconomics (14.121-14.123), macroeconomics (14.131-14.133), and econometrics (14.381), which provide a foundation in economic theory and empirical methods.

Electives: Students choose from a range of elective courses in specialized areas, such as international trade, public finance, labor economics, and econometrics, which allow them to develop their interests and expertise.
Field Courses: Students take field courses (14.4xx) that provide advanced training in specific areas of economics, such as economic development, industrial organization, or monetary economics.
learningOutcomes: Understand and apply microeconomic and macroeconomic theories to analyze economic phenomena.
Use econometric methods to analyze economic data and test hypotheses.
Develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills in the context of economic analysis.
Communicate complex economic ideas and results effectively in written and oral form.
Apply economic principles to real-world problems and policy issues.
additionalInformation: Students must complete the General Institute Requirements in addition to the major requirements. Restricted electives and GIRs limit flexibility.
